summary: This document is a forwarded email chain from September 2021, containing a May 2020 GoFundMe message from a man named Brian Vickers to an unspecified recipient. Vickers expresses sympathy for the recipient's health challenges and history of abuse, shares his personal and his wife's traumatic experiences, offers medical connections and support, and mentions his involvement with a foundation called Families Against Cult Teachings (F.A.C.T.). The email was forwarded within the FBI in the context of Epstein/Maxwell discovery.

persons.name: Brian Vickers
persons.role: Email author, board member of F.A.C.T.
persons.context: Author of a GoFundMe message expressing sympathy and offering support to an unnamed recipient, sharing personal and his wife's traumatic experiences, and mentioning his role on the board of Families Against Cult Teachings.

persons.name: Shannon Meyer
persons.context: FBI recipient (SE) of the forwarded email chain regarding Epstein/Maxwell discovery.

connections.description: Brian Vickers describes his wife as a survivor of abandonment, sexual abuse, and trafficking starting from age 13.

events.title: GoFundMe Message from Brian Vickers
events.description: Brian Vickers sends a message via GoFundMe to an unnamed recipient, offering emotional support, sharing personal trauma stories, and offering medical connections.

events.title: Email Forwarding for Epstein/Maxwell Discovery
events.description: An email chain, including the GoFundMe message, is forwarded within the FBI, labeled as part of 'Epstein/Maxwell Discovery'.

keyFacts: A GoFundMe message from Brian Vickers is included in FBI materials related to Epstein/Maxwell discovery.
Brian Vickers claims to be on the board of a foundation called Families Against Cult Teachings (F.A.C.T.), which targets cults and trafficking.
Vickers describes his wife as a survivor of childhood sexual abuse, trafficking, and rape by three different men over 20 years.
The document shows the FBI collecting and reviewing various forms of correspondence, including GoFundMe messages, as part of its investigation.
The primary recipient of the GoFundMe message is not named, but the context suggests it may be a victim or person connected to the Epstein/Maxwell case.
